Problem:
Consider a system governed by the heat equation \\( u_t = \\Delta u \\), where \\( u(t,x) \\) is the temperature distribution over a domain. We investigate the effect of introducing a source term \\( S(x) \\) applied from time t = 0, described mathematically as \\( u_t = \\Delta u + S(x) \\).

If the source term \\( S(x) \\) is applied at t = 0 and then the system is allowed to evolve according to \\( u_t = \\Delta u + S(x) \\) without further intervention, will the temperature distribution at time T, \\( u(T,x) \\), be different from the scenario where no source term was applied?
Explanation: Applying the source term \\( S(x) \\) adds energy to the system and alters its initial and boundary conditions. The additional term \\( S(x) \\) in the heat equation introduces a new component to the temperature distribution throughout the evolution, making \\( u(T,x) \\) fundamentally different from the case without \\( S(x) \\).
